title: Authors and Citation
text: Oelschläger L (2025). optimizeR: Unified Framework Numerical Optimizers. R package version 1.2.0, https://loelschlaeger.de/optimizeR/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {optimizeR: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers},   author = {Lennart Oelschläger},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.2.0},   url = {https://loelschlaeger.de/optimizeR/}, }

what: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers in R
title: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers in R
text: optimizeR package provides object-oriented framework optimizer functions R offers convenience minimizing maximizing. ❌ won’t need package … already know optimizer want use happy constraints (e.g., minimization first function argument possible), want compare optimizers already covered {optimx}, framework compare 30 optimizers, search new optimization algorithms (package implement optimizer functions ). ✅ might find package useful want … compare optimizer function (also covered optimx frameworks; see CRAN Task View: Optimization Mathematical Programming overview), consistently named inputs outputs across different optimizers (generally case), view optimizers objects (can helpful implementing packages depend optimization), use optimizers minimization maximization, optimize one function argument, measure computation time set time limit long optimization tasks.

title: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers in R
text: following demo bit artificial showcases package purpose. Let’s assume want maximize function two arguments, interrupt optimization exceeds 10 seconds, compare performance optimizers stats::nlm pracma::nelder_mead. can task optimizeR. can install released package version CRAN : load package via library("optimizeR") ready go. 1. Define objective function Let f:ℝ4→ℝf:\mathbb{R}^4\\mathbb{R} = b = 20, negative Ackley function global maximum x = y = 0:  want keep b fixed optimize x y (also single numeric values). Two problems occur optimize f say stats::nlm directly: two target arguments (x y) position target argument first place. artifacts allowed stats::nlm available optimizers, supported optimizeR. just define objective object later can pass optimizers: 2. Create optimizer objects Now defined objective function, let’s define optimizer objects. stats::nlm, one-liner: optimizeR package provides dictionary optimizers, can directly selected via argument. overview available optimizers, see: fact, optimizer contained dictionary can put optimizeR framework setting = "custom" first… … using $definition() method next: 3. Set time limit optimizer object field called $seconds equals Inf default. can optionally set different, single numeric value set time limit seconds optimization: Note everything (especially compiled C code) can technically timed , see help site help("withTimeout", package = "R.utils") details. 4. Maximize objective function optimizer object two methods $maximize() $minimize() function maximization minimization, respectively. methods require values two arguments objective (either objective object defined just function) initial (initial parameter vector optimizer start) optionally accepts additional arguments passed optimizer objective function. Note inputs objective function initial parameter values named consistently across optimizers, output values optimal parameter vector maximimum function value also named consistently across optimizers, output contains initial parameter values optimization time seconds additionally optimizer-specific elements, pracma::nelder_mead outperforms stats::nlm terms optimization time convergence global maximum.
code: install.packages("optimizeR") f <- function(a, b, x, y) {   a * exp(-0.2 * sqrt(0.5 * (x^2 + y^2))) + exp(0.5 * (cos(2 * pi * x) + cos(2 * pi * y))) - exp(1) - b } objective <- Objective$new(   f = f,                 # f is our objective function   target = c("x", "y"),  # x and y are the target arguments   npar = c(1, 1),        # the target arguments have both a length of 1   "a" = 20,                 "b" = 20               # a and b have fixed values ) nlm <- Optimizer$new(which = "stats::nlm") optimizer_dictionary #> <Dictionary> optimization algorithms  #> Keys:  #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3c #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3 #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3f #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3x #> - stats::nlm #> - stats::nlminb #> - stats::optim #> - ucminf::ucminf nelder_mead <- Optimizer$new(which = "custom") #> Use method `$definition()` next to define a custom optimizer. nelder_mead$definition(   algorithm = pracma::nelder_mead, # the optimization function   arg_objective = "fn",            # the argument name for the objective function   arg_initial = "x0",              # the argument name for the initial values   out_value = "fmin",              # the element for the optimal function value in the output   out_parameter = "xmin",          # the element for the optimal parameters in the output   direction = "min"                # the optimizer minimizes ) nlm$seconds <- 10 nelder_mead$seconds <- 10 nlm$maximize(objective = objective, initial = c(3, 3)) #> $value #> [1] -6.559645 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 1.974451 1.974451 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.0242281 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 3 3 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradient #> [1] 5.757896e-08 5.757896e-08 #>  #> $code #> [1] 1 #>  #> $iterations #> [1] 6 nelder_mead$maximize(objective = objective, initial = c(3, 3)) #> $value #> [1] 0 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 0 0 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.008966923 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 3 3 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $count #> [1] 105 #>  #> $info #> $info$solver #> [1] "Nelder-Mead" #>  #> $info$restarts #> [1] 0

title: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers in R

title: Specify objective function object — Objective
text: Objective object specifies framework objective function numerical optimization.

title: Specify objective function object — Objective
text: Objective object.

title: Specify objective function object — Objective
text: objective_name [character(1)] label objective function. fixed_arguments [character(), read-] name(s) fixed argument(s) (). seconds [numeric(1)] time limit seconds. Computations interrupted prematurely seconds exceeded. time limit seconds = Inf (default). Note limitations documented setTimeLimit. hide_warnings [logical(1)] Hide warnings evaluating objective function? verbose [logical(1)] Print status messages? npar [integer(), read-] length target argument. target [character(), read-] argument name(s) get optimized. gradient_specified [logical(1), read-] Whether gradient function specified via $set_gradient(). hessian_specified [logical(1), read-] Whether Hessian function specified via $set_hessian().

title: Specify objective function object — Objective
text: Objective$new() Objective$set_argument() Objective$get_argument() Objective$remove_argument() Objective$set_gradient() Objective$set_hessian() Objective$evaluate() Objective$evaluate_gradient() Objective$evaluate_hessian() Objective$print() Objective$clone()

text: Creates new Objective object.

title: Specify objective function object — Objective
text: f [function] function optimized. expected f least one numeric argument. , expected return value f structure numeric(1), .e. single numeric value. target [character()] argument name(s) get optimized. target arguments must numeric. Can NULL (default), first function argument selected. npar [integer()] length target argument, .e., length(s) numeric vector argument(s) specified target. ... Optionally additional function arguments fixed optimization.

Can NULL (default), first function argument selected. npar [integer()] length target argument, .e., length(s) numeric vector argument(s) specified target. ... Ignored $gradient_specified FALSE. .gradient_attribute_name [character(1)\]\cr relevant .gradient_as_attribute = TRUE`. case, attribute name gradient (available). .hessian_as_attribute [`logical(1)] Add value Hessian function attribute output? attribute name defined via .hessian_attribute_name argument. Ignored $hessian_specified FALSE. .hessian_attribute_name [character(1)\]\cr relevant .hessian_as_attribute = TRUE`. case, attribute name Hessian (available). ... title: Specify objective function object — Objective
code: ### define log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture model llk <- function(mu, sd, lambda, data) {   sd <- exp(sd)   lambda <- plogis(lambda)   cluster_1 <- lambda * dnorm(data, mu[1], sd[1])   cluster_2 <- (1 - lambda) * dnorm(data, mu[2], sd[2])   sum(log(cluster_1 + cluster_2)) }  ### optimize over the first three arguments, the 'data' argument is constant objective <- Objective$new(   f = llk, target = c("mu", "sd", "lambda"), npar = c(2, 2, 1),   data = faithful$eruptions )  ### evaluate at 1:5 (1:2 is passed to mu, 3:4 to sd, and 5 to lambda) objective$evaluate(1:5) #> [1] -1069.623

title: Specify numerical optimizer object — Optimizer
text: Optimizer object defines numerical optimizer based optimization algorithm implemented R. main advantage working Optimizer object instead using optimization function directly lies standardized inputs outputs. R function fulfills following four constraints can defined Optimizer object: must input function, objective function optimized. must input numeric vector, initial values optimizer starts. must ... argument additional parameters passed objective function. output must named list, including optimal function value optimal parameter vector.

title: Specify numerical optimizer object — Optimizer
text: label [character(1)] label optimizer. algorithm [function] optimization algorithm. arg_objective [character(1)] argument name objective function algorithm. arg_initial [character(1)] argument name initial values algorithm. arg_lower [character(1) | NA] Optionally argument name lower parameter bound algorithm. Can NA available. arg_upper [character(1) | NA] Optionally argument name upper parameter bound algorithm. Can NA available. arg_gradient [character(1) | NA] Optionally argument name gradient function algorithm. Can NA available. arg_hessian [character(1) | NA] Optionally argument name Hessian function algorithm. Can NA available. gradient_as_attribute [logical(1)] relevant arg_gradient NA. case, algorithm expect gradient attribute objective function output (example nlm)? case, arg_gradient defines attribute name. hessian_as_attribute [logical(1)] relevant arg_hessian NA. case, algorithm expect Hessian attribute objective function output (example nlm)? case, arg_hessian defines attribute name. out_value [character(1)] element name optimal function value output list algorithm. out_parameter [character(1)] element name optimal parameters output list algorithm. direction [character(1)] Either "min" (optimizer minimizes) "max" (optimizer maximizes). arguments [list()] Custom arguments algorithm. Defaults used arguments specified. seconds [numeric(1)] time limit seconds. Optimization interrupted prematurely seconds exceeded. time limit seconds = Inf (default). Note limitations documented setTimeLimit. hide_warnings [logical(1)] Hide warnings optimization? output_ignore [character()] Elements ignore (include) optimization output.

title: Specify numerical optimizer object — Optimizer
code: ### Task: compare minimization with 'stats::nlm' and 'pracma::nelder_mead'  # 1. define objective function and initial values objective <- TestFunctions::TF_ackley initial <- c(3, 3)  # 2. get overview of optimizers available in dictionary optimizer_dictionary$keys #> [1] "lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3c" "lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3"  "lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3f" #> [4] "lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3x" "stats::nlm"         "stats::nlminb"      #> [7] "stats::optim"       "ucminf::ucminf"      # 3. define 'nlm' optimizer nlm <- Optimizer$new(which = "stats::nlm")  # 4. define the 'pracma::nelder_mead' optimizer (not contained in the dictionary) nelder_mead <- Optimizer$new(which = "custom") #> Use method `$definition()` next to define a custom optimizer. nelder_mead$definition(   algorithm = pracma::nelder_mead, # the optimization function   arg_objective = "fn",            # the argument name for the objective function   arg_initial = "x0",              # the argument name for the initial values   out_value = "fmin",              # the element for the optimal function value in the output   out_parameter = "xmin",          # the element for the optimal parameters in the output   direction = "min"                # the optimizer minimizes )  # 5. compare the minimization results nlm$minimize(objective, initial) #> $value #> [1] 6.559645 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 1.974451 1.974451 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.03985429 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 3 3 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradient #> [1] 5.757896e-08 5.757896e-08 #>  #> $code #> [1] 1 #>  #> $iterations #> [1] 6 #>  nelder_mead$minimize(objective, initial) #> $value #> [1] 4.440892e-16 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 0 0 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.01237774 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 3 3 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $count #> [1] 105 #>  #> $info #> $info$solver #> [1] "Nelder-Mead" #>  #> $info$restarts #> [1] 0 #>  #>    ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `Optimizer$minimize` ## ------------------------------------------------  Optimizer$new("stats::nlm")$   minimize(objective = function(x) x^4 + 3*x - 5, initial = 2) #> $value #> [1] -7.044261 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] -0.9085614 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.001808882 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 2 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradient #> [1] -6.068035e-06 #>  #> $code #> [1] 1 #>  #> $iterations #> [1] 7 #>   ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `Optimizer$maximize` ## ------------------------------------------------  Optimizer$new("stats::nlm")$   maximize(objective = function(x) -x^4 + 3*x - 5, initial = 2) #> $value #> [1] -2.955739 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 0.9085598 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.002276182 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 2 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradient #> [1] -3.801404e-07 #>  #> $code #> [1] 1 #>  #> $iterations #> [1] 8 #>   ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `Optimizer$optimize` ## ------------------------------------------------  objective <- function(x) -x^4 + 3*x - 5 optimizer <- Optimizer$new("stats::nlm") optimizer$optimize(objective = objective, initial = 2, direction = "min") #> $value #> [1] -1.012458e+16 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 10031 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.001550198 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 2 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradient #> [1] -4.037322e+12 #>  #> $code #> [1] 5 #>  #> $iterations #> [1] 6 #>  optimizer$optimize(objective = objective, initial = 2, direction = "max") #> $value #> [1] -2.955739 #>  #> $parameter #> [1] 0.9085598 #>  #> $seconds #> [1] 0.002220392 #>  #> $initial #> [1] 2 #>  #> $error #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $gradient #> [1] -3.801404e-07 #>  #> $code #> [1] 1 #>  #> $iterations #> [1] 8 #>

title: Switch between parameter spaces — ParameterSpaces
text: ParameterSpaces object manages two related parameter spaces: Optimization Space (optimization) Interpretation Space (easier interpretation). Optimization Space, parameters stored numeric vector, standard format numerical optimizers. Interpretation Space, parameters stored list can take different formats (e.g., matrix). user can define transformation functions (necessarily bijective) switch spaces via $o2i() $i2o() methods.

title: Switch between parameter spaces — ParameterSpaces
text: ParameterSpaces$new() ParameterSpaces$print() ParameterSpaces$switch() ParameterSpaces$o2i() ParameterSpaces$i2o() ParameterSpaces$clone()

title: Switch between parameter spaces — ParameterSpaces
code: ### Log-likelihood function of two-class Gaussian mixture model with ### parameter vector `theta` that consists of ### - `mu`, mean vector of length 2 ### - `sd`, standard deviation vector of length 2, must be positive ### - `lambda`, class probability of length 1, must be between 0 and 1  normal_mixture_llk <- function(theta, data) {   mu <- theta[1:2]   sd <- exp(theta[3:4])   lambda <- plogis(theta[5])   c1 <- lambda * dnorm(data, mu[1], sd[1])   c2 <- (1 - lambda) * dnorm(data, mu[2], sd[2])   sum(log(c1 + c2)) }  ### define parameter spaces ### - `mu` needs no transformation ### - `sd` needs to be real in optimization space and positive in ###    interpretation space ### - `lambda` needs to be real and of length `1` in optimization space, and ###    a probability vector of length `2` in interpretation space  normal_mixture_spaces <- ParameterSpaces$   new(     parameter_names = c("mu", "sd", "lambda"),     parameter_lengths_in_o_space = c(2, 2, 1)   )$   o2i(     "mu" = function(x) x,     "sd" = function(x) exp(x),     "lambda" = function(x) c(plogis(x), 1 - plogis(x))   )$   i2o(     "mu" = function(x) x,     "sd" = function(x) log(x),     "lambda" = function(x) qlogis(x[1])   )  ### switch between parameter spaces  par <- list(                             # parameters in interpretation space   "mu" = c(2, 4),   "sd" = c(0.5, 1),   "lambda" = c(0.4, 0.6) ) (x <- normal_mixture_spaces$switch(par)) # switch to optimization space #> [1]  2.0000000  4.0000000 -0.6931472  0.0000000 -0.4054651 normal_mixture_llk(   theta = x, data = datasets::faithful$eruptions ) #> [1] -382.1072 normal_mixture_spaces$switch(x)          # switch back #> $mu #> [1] 2 4 #>  #> $sd #> [1] 0.5 1.0 #>  #> $lambda #> [1] 0.4 0.6 #>

what: optimizeR: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers — optimizeR-package
title: optimizeR: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers — optimizeR-package
text: Provides unified object-oriented framework numerical optimizers R. Allows minimization maximization optimizer, optimization one function argument, measuring computation time, setting time limit long optimization tasks.

title: optimizeR: Unified Framework for Numerical Optimizers — optimizeR-package
text: Maintainer: Lennart Oelschläger oelschlaeger.lennart@gmail.com (ORCID) contributors: Marius Ötting marius.oetting@uni-bielefeld.de (ORCID) [contributor]

title: Dictionary of optimizer functions — optimizer_dictionary
text: dictionary currently included numerical optimizer functions {optimizeR} package.

title: Dictionary of optimizer functions — optimizer_dictionary
text: R6 object class Dictionary.

title: Dictionary of optimizer functions — optimizer_dictionary
code: print(optimizer_dictionary) #> <Dictionary> optimization algorithms  #> Keys:  #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3c #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3 #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3f #> - lbfgsb3c::lbfgsb3x #> - stats::nlm #> - stats::nlminb #> - stats::optim #> - ucminf::ucminf

title: optimizeR 1.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-04-24 Gradient, Hessian, parameter bounds can now passed Optimizer objects. old S3 interface removed, hence, functions define_optimizer(), optimizer_nlm(), optimizer_optim(), new_optimizer(), validate_optimizer(), apply_optimizer() longer available. Please use R6 interface instead, via Optimizer$new() corresponding methods, see help("Optimizer", "optimizeR") details.

title: optimizeR 1.1.3
text: CRAN release: 2025-03-27 ParameterSpaces allows specify parameters used transformations. useful general ParameterSpaces object defined nested sets parameters.

title: optimizeR 1.1.2
text: CRAN release: 2024-11-27 New ParameterSpaces R6 object transform parameters optimization interpretation space.

title: optimizeR 1.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2024-06-19 Objective object now allows different types output structures objective function, template can provided via $output_template field.

title: optimizeR 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-05-27 Optimizer object new method optimize can used minimization maximization setting argument direction. method Objective$initialize(), renamed argument objective -> f. method Objective$initialize(), target = NULL (new default), first argument f taken target argument.

title: optimizeR 1.0.5
text: CRAN release: 2024-02-28 Removed install_optimizer_packages().

title: optimizeR 1.0.4
text: CRAN release: 2024-02-05 Fixed bug added test cases fixed arguments NULL.

title: optimizeR 1.0.3
text: CRAN release: 2024-01-31 Fixed bug creating error message case time . Added checks objective, initial, ellipsis argument optimizer function. Added verbose argument methods $get_argument() $remove_argument() Objective object. Added field fixed_arguments Objective object returns names fixed arguments. Fixed bug proper backwards compatibility.

title: optimizeR 1.0.2
text: CRAN release: 2024-01-14 Small bug fixes. Backward compatibility optimizeR version 0.3.3.

title: optimizeR 1.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-11-08 Fixed wrong values "out_value" "out_parameter" optimizer dictionary entry stats::optim.

title: optimizeR 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-11-04 Instead using S3 classes, treat optimizers R6 objects now.

title: optimizeR 0.3.3
text: CRAN release: 2023-09-27 Removed package start-message. Added .direction argument define_optimizer() specify whether optimizer minimizes maximizes. Added dot argument names define_optimizer() avoid clashes ... argument. Removed dependency glue. Using TestFunctions::TF_ackley instead implementation Ackley function (validation).

title: optimizeR 0.3.2
text: CRAN release: 2023-03-25 Just added package logo created package website (https://loelschlaeger.de/optimizeR) {pkgdown} package. code changes.

title: optimizeR 0.3.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-03-05 define_optimizer(), now validate = FALSE default.

title: optimizeR 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-01-22 Function set_optimizer() renamed define_optimizer(). Inputs define_optimizer() renamed clarity: opt_fun -> optimizer f -> objective p -> initial v -> value z -> parameter out_ign -> output_ignore test_par -> validation_settings Elements input validation_settings simplified, please see documentation define_optimizer(). Elements output apply_optimizer() renamed clarity: v -> value z -> parameter time -> seconds (now just numeric) Element initial (starting parameter vector) added output apply_optimizer().

title: optimizeR 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-12-02 functions renamed: optimizeR() -> apply_optimizer() set_optimizer_nlm() -> optimizer_nlm() set_optimizer_optim() -> optimizer_optim() Functions is_number(), try_silent(), timed(), .call_timed() longer exported. Function try_silent_timed() removed.

title: optimizeR 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-23 Initial CRAN release.
